thread.title: Aust dollar drops toward US70c
thread.title_full: Aust dollar drops toward US70c | Business Spectator

author: AAP with a staff reporter
title: Aust dollar drops toward US70c
text:
The Australian dollar has followed US stocks lower on concerns the US Federal Reserve might raise its interest rate next week.
At 7am (AEST), the local unit was trading at US70.04c, down from US70.49c on Wednesday.
Recent reports show that Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) officials aren't near complete agreement to start raising the interest rate heading into the week of private discussions before their September 16-17 policy meeting.
BK Asset Management managing director Kathy Lien said next week's US interest rate decision is a key focus for markets.
"Investors have not given up on the possibility of a September rate hike from the Federal Reserve but the chance is low and the decision is close based on the uncertainty in the global economy," she said.
"The Chinese economy is slowing and despite Premier Li Keqiang's reassurance that growth is in the `proper range,' the government is worried."
After 7am (AEST, the Australian dollar plunged as low as US69.81c after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut the official cash rate as expected and said further easing seems likely.
RBNZ Governor Graeme Wheeler said the rate cut was warranted because of the "softening" New Zealand economy.
Ms Lien said a key driver for the Australian dollar on Thursday will be the release of the August jobs report.
The unemployment rate is expected to ease from its 13-year high of 6.3 per cent in July, mainly because of a fall in the number of people looking for work.
